response.answer_text: This guy…  In modern politics dating back at least 80 years, the Vice Presidential nominee has been hand-picked by, or at least placed on the ticket without the objection of, the Presidential nominee. In the 1940’s, FDR hand-picked Henry Wallace and agreed to Harry Truman when the Democratic Party rebelled at the thought of Wallace succeeding him. In 1948 Truman hand-picked Alben Barkley after his first two choices decided they didn’t want to run on a ticket with him. The GOP wasn’t going to refuse anyone Dwight Eisenhower picked in 1952, which unfortunately infected this nation with its first real case of Richard Nixon. John Kennedy chose Lyndon Johnson in 1960 against the advice of many (including his own brother). Four years later, Johnson dangled the Vice Presidency over Hubert Humphrey’s head one does a chew toy over a dog. In 1968 Nixon shocked the entire GOP by picking Spiro Agnew. Despite trying to jettison Agnew wherever he could pretty much throughout their first term (offering him among other things a Supreme Court appointment, which Agnew refused), in ’72 Agnew literally bulldozed his way into the Oval Office and manipulated Nixon into renominating him. Gerald Ford at least gave tacit approval to Bob Dole in 1976 to placate the Reaganesque wing of the GOP, while Jimmy Carter hand picked Walter Mondale after conducting the first modern Vice Presidential search. Ronald Reagan hand picked former President Ford as his running mate in 1980 and almost chose him, but they couldn’t reach an agreement on how that arrangement would work… so Reagan picked Bush at the suggestion of one of his staffers. Bush hand picked Dan Quayle. Clinton chose Gore. George W. Bush basically let Dick Cheney pick himself. Barack Obama picked (hopefully) future President Biden. Trump picked Race Bannon wannabe Mike Pence. The one at the top of the ticket invariably picks the one at the bottom. It’s the first presidential prerogative, and it’s the first indicator of whether a nominee is well suited to the office. Sometimes they are (Ford, Carter, Reagan and Clinton chose exceptionally well). Sometimes they aren’t (Nixon with Agnew, Bush with Quayle, Kerry with John Edwards, Trump with Pence, and worst of all John McCain with Sarah Palin).

I’ve been saying since Super Tuesday that his best choice would be Abrams. She’d inject a much needed boost of energy to his campaign and also GOTV the Black and youth vote. Don’t get me wrong. Biden or any D will win the youth and Black vote but not with overwhelming turnouts such as Obama enjoyed. Abrams will not match Obama level enthusiasm by any means but she’ll do wonders compared to most if not all others. She’ll lock the win for Biden. Biden and the DNC may be too fuddy-duddy to accept the noise that Abrams will bring since for sure she’ll overshadow him both in voter interest and enthusiasm. I’ll go with an almost win by Bottoms. IMO, she’ll sink Biden due to the treatment of the Wendy’s shooting policeman. Like it or don’t, that shooting was by the books and not at all analogous to the Chauvin / Floyd killing. While Bottoms may bring out some Black vote, she won’t much and not that much youth either. However, her cowardly behavior will suppress the white vote significantly. IMO, she’ll be a net loss for Biden. I desperately do not wish to see him win. Therefore, I hope the rumors are correct and that he’s settled on Warren. That’d be like Trump dropping Pence and asking Bolton to be his VP.
